abstract.p: Roberta T Zuvers letter on Mar 9 article on mill town's fight for survival (S)

block.p: A chart with ''Downsized, but Not Out: A Mill Town's Tale'' (March 9) said the first electric blanket was believed to have been made in 1946.
A chart with ''Downsized, but Not Out: A Mill Town's Tale'' (March 9) said the first electric blanket was believed to have been made in 1946.

I know otherwise. I received an electric blanket as a Christmas gift in 1942. I was in college, sleeping in an unheated attic-dormitory, weighed down by several heavy woolen blankets that did not keep me snug and warm.

My fiance had gone to work for General Electric in Schenectady, N.Y. Early in December 1942, he made a visit to the employees' store, where electric blankets were on display. He bought one and immediately sent it to me in Indiana. I have not been without an electric blanket since (and have been married 53 1/2 years to that thoughtful electrical engineer).

Those early blankets required a transformer, housed in a black plastic case about the size and weight of a five-pound bag of sugar. It strapped to the bed slats; one cord plugged into the blanket, and another into an electrical outlet.
